content: AMENDMENTS TO IMPACT AID PROGRAM. Amendments to the Impact Aid Program include changes to payments related to federal acquisition of real property and payments for eligible federally connected children. Key changes include entitlement instead of eligibility for payments and the removal of certain subsections. The amendments to the Impact Aid Program involve changes to payments for federally connected children, including entitlement instead of eligibility for payments. The amendments to the Impact Aid Program involve changes to payments for federally connected children, including entitlement for payments instead of eligibility. Amendments include removing "maximum amount" and replacing it with "amount," as well as changing "is eligible" to "is entitled." Additionally, in paragraph (2), changes include replacing "From the amount appropriated under section 8014(b) for a fiscal year, the Secretary is authorized to" with "The Secretary shall." The amendments involve changing eligibility to entitlement in the Impact Aid Program, including replacing "eligible" with "entitled" and "eligibility" with "entitlement" in various clauses and headings. Amendments to the Impact Aid Program involve changing references from section 8014(e) to subsection (c) and authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2009. Additionally, facilities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 are also authorized appropriations as necessary. Amendments to the Impact Aid Program authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2009 under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The text chunk discusses appropriations and entitlements for payments to local educational agencies under sections 8002 and 8003 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also includes a rule of construction stating that the provisions do not entitle individuals to assistance under any program funded under this title. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on October 1, 2003, or the date of enactment, whichever is later.
